election_record.label: Pennsylvania 1808 Governor

overview.note: "The Federalists and Quids were unable to reach any agreement. In a Constitutionalist caucus at Lancaster on January 29, 1808, the Quids proposed Joseph Heister and John Spayd as candidates for Governor. The former's name was later withdrawn; and they united behind Spayd, who was Hiester's son-in-law and president judge of the judicial district which included Berks County. The Federalists for the most part backed James Ross, their candidate in 1799 and 1802 . . . Ross's nomination ended any possibilities of a compromise among the Constitutionalists in the legislature. The Federalists and Quids met twice in March, but it was to no avail. The Quids refused the Federalist proposal for a nominating convention, and the latter walked out of the caucus rather than be bound by the nomination of Spayd. The Quids then adjourned their meeting to March 23, 1808, when they made formal announcement of their nominees. They included Spayd as candidate for Governor." Higginbotham, Sanford W. The Keystone in the Democratic Arch: Pennsylvania Politics, 1800-1816. Philadelphia: Pennyslvania Historical and Museum Commission, 1952. 154-155.

sub_unit.name: Armstrong
sub_unit.note: Journal of the Pennsylvania State Senate for 1808 lists 527 votes for Simon Snyder and 206 votes for James Ross in Armstrong County.
The Journal of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives, 1808 lists 527 votes for Simon Snyder and 206 votes for James Ross in Armstrong County.

sub_unit.name: Bedford
sub_unit.note: Journal of the Pennsylvania State Senate for 1808 lists 844 votes for James Ross in Bedford County.
The Journal of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives, 1808 lists 844 votes for James Ross in Bedford County.

The True American and Commercial Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 1442 votes for Simon Snyder and 864 votes for James Ross in Bedford County. October 22, 1808. November 14, 1808. November 23, 1808.

sub_unit.name: Hopewell
sub_unit.note: The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) reports 144 votes for Simon Snyder and 71 votes for James Ross in Hopewell, Bedford County.

sub_unit.name: Berks
sub_unit.note: The Freeman's Journal, and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 3458 total votes for Simon Snyder in Berks County.
The United States' Gazette (Philadelphia, PA) reports 3458 total votes for Simon Snyder in Berks County.
The True American and Commercial Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 1221 total votes for James Ross in Berks County. November 14, 1808. November 23, 1808.
